steps.title: Remove the Jokers from the deck, then shuffle it.
steps.content: Remove the Jokers from the deck, then shuffle it. The Joker cards aren’t required in a game of Slap Jack, so find them and set them aside. Once they’re gone, shuffle the deck 2-3 times to make sure all the cards are mixed up. There are 2 Jokers in a standard deck of playing cards.

steps.title: Gather 2-5 players and deal all the cards out evenly.
steps.content: Gather 2-5 players and deal all the cards out evenly. Slap Jack works best with 2-5 players, but you could squeeze in an extra 1 or 2. Gather everyone around a table, then deal all the cards face-down, starting with the player to your left and working clockwise around the table. Make sure each player gets the same number of cards, and deal until there are no more cards left in the deck. [1] X Research source Don’t peek at your cards! Keep them face-down in a neat pile in front of you. Set any extra cards face-up in a stack in the middle of the table. These cards will start the game.

steps.title: Start the game by placing a card face-up in the center of the table.
steps.content: Start the game by placing a card face-up in the center of the table. The player to the left of the dealer takes the top card off their own stack and places it face-up in the middle of the table, so everyone can see it. This starts the game. [2] X Research source If you had leftover cards while dealing, play this first card on top of those.

steps.title: Take turns placing a single card face-up on the center stack.
steps.content: Take turns placing a single card face-up on the center stack. Players take turns clockwise around the table. On their turn, a player takes the top card of their personal pile and flips it face-up onto the center stack of cards. Slap Jack is a very fast game, so get ready for things to move rather quickly. Try to keep the center pile neat and tidy, even when the game is moving quickly.

steps.title: Slap the Jack card as soon as someone plays it.
steps.content: Slap the Jack card as soon as someone plays it. As the other players take their turns, keep an eye out for a Jack card to appear. As soon as you see a Jack, reach out and slap the card as quickly as you can! [3] X Research source You don't have to wait until it's your turn to slap a Jack, but keep your hands close to your own pile—no hovering over the middle pile while you wait. The number of cards you win depends on how many cards are played since the last Jack made an appearance.

steps.title: Take the entire center pile of cards if you slapped the Jack first.
steps.content: Take the entire center pile of cards if you slapped the Jack first. This is the aim of the game! If you’re the first player to slap a Jack when it appears, take all the cards in the middle of the table (including the Jack) and shuffle them into your own personal pile. More cards means you stay in the game longer. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Start a new pile in the middle if you slapped the deck.
steps.content: Start a new pile in the middle if you slapped the deck. If you slapped the Jack and won the hand, start the game again by playing the top card of your face-down pile into the center of the table, face-up. This starts the pile over again, so the next players can build upon it. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Gather all the cards to win the game.
steps.content: Gather all the cards to win the game. The aim of the game is to take every single card by slapping the center pile. As you play, some players will run out of cards, while others will start collecting more and more. Win Slap Jack by collecting the entire deck of cards! [6] X Research source

steps.title: Give 1 card to another player if you slap a card other than a Jack.
steps.content: Give 1 card to another player if you slap a card other than a Jack. If you hit a card before the Jack is played or slap another card while trying to get to the Jack, you must give the top card of your own pile to the player who played the card. They add this card to the top of their face-down pile, without peeking. For example, if you hit the 8 of Spades instead of the Jack of Clubs, give your top card to the player who played the 8 of Spades. Or, if another player plays a 7 on top of a Jack while you were reaching to slap it, but you slap the 7 instead, you still take the penalty.

steps.title: Slap your way back into the game after you run out of cards.
steps.content: Slap your way back into the game after you run out of cards. If all of your cards wind up in the pile, that’s okay! You have 1 more chance to redeem yourself and stay in the game by being the first to slap the next Jack. If you do, collect all of the cards in the pile and keep playing. [7] X Research source If you do not slap the next Jack first, you are out of the game.

steps.title: Play Rock, Paper, Scissors to settle a slap tie.
steps.content: Play Rock, Paper, Scissors to settle a slap tie. Sometimes, 2 players will slap the pile at the same time, and they probably won’t agree who got there first. In this case, play a single round of Rock, Paper, Scissors to decide who gets to take the pile. Or, if another player clearly saw what happened, let them declare a winner and break the tie.

steps.title: Slap “card sandwiches” to add extra challenge to the game.
steps.content: Slap “card sandwiches” to add extra challenge to the game. Some groups play with a bonus rule, which is that you can also slap the center pile when you see a “sandwich,” which is a card played between 2 cards of the same number, like a 4 between two 7s. If you spot and slap a sandwich, you take the entire center pile, just like slapping a Jack. [8] X Research source For example, Player A plays a Queen, Player B plays a 6, and Player C plays another Queen. Any player could slap this sandwich to take the pile.

steps.title: Slap any doubles to make the game more chaotic.
steps.content: Slap any doubles to make the game more chaotic. With this rule, players can also slap the pile any time 2 of the same card is played one right after the other, like a 2 and then another 2, or King after a King. This adds a healthy amount of chaos and excitement to the table, but get ready to slap like crazy, since it happens pretty often!

steps.title: Play with a time limit to shorten the game.
steps.content: Play with a time limit to shorten the game. Some games can go for quite a while, as players win and lose cards over and over again. To make sure things go quickly, set a time for 5 or 10 minutes once the first card is played. The player with the most cards at the end of the time limit wins. [9] X Research source
